content.question: Which of the following accurately compares Milosz’s perspective in the passage with the ideas of European existentialism?

choices.label: Both Milosz and the existentialists were sharply critical of communist society and the suffering communist policies had inflicted on the peoples of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
Milosz was interested in the question of why individuals act in the way that they do, but existentialists did not share that interest.

In contrast to the existentialists, Milosz followed a Marxist materialist model in explaining human behavior and class conflict, but he shared the existentialists’ skepticism of the idea of constant progress.

Like the existentialists, Milosz was interested in the alienation of the individual in the face of absurd social circumstances, but he did not share existentialists’ critical attitude toward Western society.

content.answer: Like the existentialists, Milosz was interested in the alienation of the individual in the face of absurd social circumstances, but he did not share existentialists’ critical attitude toward Western society.
